description: The Cisco Cybersecurity Fundamentals show is based around the released exam objectives for SECFND Exam 210-250. The show will cover every exam objective to help prepare those interested in becoming CCNA CyberOps certified.  The show aids those preparing for the first of two exams leading to that certification by helping understand cybersecurity basics, foundational networking and security knowledge and develop skills needed in preparation for the second (SECOPS) exam.
descriptionMD: The Cisco Cybersecurity Fundamentals show is based around the released exam objectives for SECFND Exam 210-250. The show will cover every exam objective to help prepare those interested in becoming CCNA CyberOps certified.  The show aids those preparing for the first of two exams leading to that certification by helping understand cybersecurity basics, foundational networking and security knowledge and develop skills needed in preparation for the second (SECOPS) exam.
name: CCNA Cyber Ops (210-250 SECFND)
subtitle: Cisco Cybersecurity Fundamentals

episodes.description: The Cisco Cybersecurity Fundamentals show is based around the released exam objectives for SECFND Exam 210-250. The show will cover every exam objective to help prepare those interested in becoming CCNA CyberOps certified. The show aids those preparing for the first of two exams leading to that certification by helping understand cybersecurity basics, foundational networking and security knowledge and develop skills needed in preparation for the second (SECOPS) exam.
episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: This is the first episode in the Cisco Cybersecurity Fundamentals course which is geared to help you obtain the CCNA Cyber Ops certification. In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee discuss The Open Systems Interconnect (OSI) model and look at the seven integrated layers. This show examines the Application, Presentation, and Session layers.
episodes.title: Describe Network Models

episodes.description: This episode picks up from the previous one where Ronnie and Cherokee delve into the wonderful world of the OSI model. They begin describing the Transport layer, followed by the Network, Data Link and Physical.
episodes.title: Describe Network Models Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee introduce an alternative model called the TCP/IP model. You will also see a variation of the model and how both variants relate to the OSI model.
episodes.title: Describe Network Models Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee review Internet Protocol and compare and contrast the versions. They annotate why the advent IPv6 is essential and why it is important to understand these concepts.
episodes.title: Describe Basic Networking Protocols

episodes.description: This episode highlights the differences and similarities between Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and User Datagram Protocol (UDP). Ronnie and Cherokee break down what actually happens when a three way handshake occurs. They also explain Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) and dependent utilities such as ping and traceroute/tracert.
episodes.title: Describe Basic Networking Protocols Part 2

episodes.description: In this show Ronnie and Cherokee discuss the fundamentals of Domain Name System (DNS). Ronnie explains the process in which computers convert hostnames and fully qualified domain names into IP address. You will also learn associated terminology in addition to Ronnie demonstrating where you be interacting with these concepts in a production environment.
episodes.title: Describe Basic Networking Services Part 2

episodes.description: This show focuses on networking hardware. See Ronnie and Cherokee discuss details surrounding routers, switches and hubs. Specifically, you will learn the differences between the functionality of each device. Understanding how these devices work is expected at this level per Cisco objectives because it is such an integral part of our networks.
episodes.title: Describe Networking Devices Operations

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee continue to examine networking hardware. First, you will learn about an older device called a bridge. Secondly, they discuss more modern products such as Wireless Access Points (WAP) and Wireless LAN Controller (WLC).
episodes.title: Describe Networking Devices Operations Part 2

episodes.description: This show sorts thru the available Cisco security systems. First, you will see how firewalls can be implemented in a variety of ways. You will also see how Cisco incorporates an intrusion prevention system or Cisco Next Generation Intrusion Prevention System (NGIPS). Cisco also offers a comprehensive malware solution called Advances Malware Protection (AMP). Lastly, you will see devices with specific uses such as their Web Security Appliance options and their Email Security Appliance.
episodes.title: Describe Network Security Systems

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee breakdown the structure of IP addresses. They identify the distinction of host versus network bits and explain why it is important to understand the structure. You will also see them explain a high-level understanding of subnetting.
episodes.title: Describe Basic Network Addressing

episodes.description: Watch Ronnie shameless pop quiz Cherokee on subnetting. In this show you will see some exam sample questions and Cherokee and Ronnie walk thru the steps.
episodes.title: Describe Basic Network Addressing Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee explain what a Virtual Local Area Network is and why you may want to use one on your network. You will also see Ronnie demonstrate a potential security risk and learn some tips to help mitigate that risk.
episodes.title: Describe VLANS and Data Visability

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee discuss Access Control Lists (ACLs) and how to apply packet filtering. Ronnie demonstrates how to block traffic based upon IP addresses with a Cisco router.
episodes.title: Describe ACL Usage on Interfaces

episodes.description: This a continuation of the previous episode. Previously you learned how to implement basic packet filtering. In this episode you will explore the notion of firewall devices operating at higher levels of the OSI to perform additional functions.
episodes.title: Describe ACL Usage on Interfaces Part 2

episodes.description: In the last couple of shows you have seen Cherokee and Ronnie explain different levels of filtering. This show takes that concept deeper with deep packet inspection. You will learn what that means and why one would choose such a precise option for their environment.
episodes.title: Compare Different Filtering Methods

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee converse about different methods to capture packets. First, you will see inline traffic interrogation such as an IPS. Next, you will learn about Test Access Points (TAPs) and how these devices copy network traffic. Lastly, traffic mirroring is explained.
episodes.title: Compare Packet Capture Methods

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee talk about what to do with the different types of output from these packet capturing methods. First, Ronnie explains how one would utilize TAPs output followed by a demonstration of a output analysis using a traffic mirroring utility called Wireshark.
episodes.title: Compare Packet Analysis Output

episodes.description: This is a continuation of a discussion where Ronnie and Cherokee compare different methods to analyze network traffic outputs. Specifically, you will see Ronnie perform a demonstration of using Cisco NetFlow in addition to using Wireshark to obtain the same flow information.
episodes.title: Compare Packet Analysis Output Part 2

episodes.description: This show begins with Ronnie and Cherokee explaining the double entendre of Data Loss. From a security standpoint we see this term being used to describe a data breach. From a networking standpoint data loss takes on a new meaning, literally loosing or dropping packets across your network. Ronnie visually shows this concept occurring by analyzing TCP retransmits, duplicate ACK and ACKed unseen packets using Wireshark.
episodes.title: Identify Traffic Loss from Packet Analysis

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the principles of Defense-in-Depth. Here they talk in detail about the importance and practice of setting up multiple defenses that are independent "road blocks", designed to frustrate a malicious person from accessing unauthorized data.
episodes.title: Describe Defense in Depth Principles

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss key, foundational security terms and concepts. Watch as they compare/contrast Risk, Threats, Vulnerabilities, and Exploits. They also define terms such as Threat Actor, Run Book Automation(RBA), Chain of Custody, and Reverse Engineering.
episodes.title: Define Security Concepts and Terms

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue to discuss key, foundational security terms and concepts. Here they pick up by defining terms like Sliding Window Anomaly Detection, Personal Identifiable Information(PII), and Personal Health Information(PHI). They also discuss Principle of Least Privilege, Risk Scoring, Risk Reduction, and Risk Assessment.
episodes.title: Define Security Concepts and Terms Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike compare and contrast different access control models. They look at discretionary access control, mandatory access control, as well as nondiscretionary access control.
episodes.title: Understand Access Control Models

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike define several industry standard terms relating to security. They look at network and host-based antivirus, and agent-based versus agentless protection. They also talk about log collection and SIEM systems.
episodes.title: Compare Security Admin Terms

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take the time to describe in detail, foundational security management concepts which are key to maintaining a secure environment. This includes Asset management, Configuration management, Mobile Device management, Patch management, and Vulnerability management.
episodes.title: Describe Security Management Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe how crypto algorithms are used to help secure data in a digital environment. They start by explaining hash algorithms; both how they work and how they're used. Then they move on to encryption algorithms, showing you how they obfuscate data crossing a wire.
episodes.title: Describe Crypto Algorithm Usage

episodes.description: In this episode you will see Cherokee and Ronnie talk about encryption options. First, Ronnie explains and shows symmetric key encryption. You will be able to understand why one would choose symmetric over asymmetric. You will be able to see how it is faster yet not as secure as asymmetric encryption.
episodes.title: Describe Crypto Algorithm Usage Part 2

episodes.description: In this show you will see Cherokee and Ronnie conversate on the topic of digital signatures. You will see the process of digital signature creation and verification. You will see how  a digital certificate is issued, then hashed and encrypted by the senders private key.
episodes.title: Describe Digital Signature Creation

episodes.description: This episode covers all things Public Key Infrastructure. Ronnie and Cherokee talk about why one would want to implement PKI and what common implementation designs you will see. You also understand how a certificate lifecycle can be described as cyclic. You see the beginning stage, such as the certificate enrollment process,  all the way to the end of life either thru expiration or revocation and how a certificate revocation list is useful.
episodes.title: Describe PKI Operations

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee describe how the success or failure of a cryptographic exchange impact a security investigation. Understanding the underlying technologies and protocols will allow one to understand where to focus investigation efforts in the event of an attack. they discuss the pros and cons of various crypto options.
episodes.title: Describe Key Exchange Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie discuss various characteristics and considerations of SSL/TLS and it’s components. They talk about cipher-suites, securing communications and various protocols that use SSL/TLS. They also look at X.509 certificates and the attributes associated with certificates.
episodes.title: Describe SSL TLS Components

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie continue their discussion on various characteristics and considerations of SSL/TLS and it’s components. They talk about secure key exchange and the process involved when client and server perform a key change. Finally, they will discuss protocol versions and considerations while also looking at the Public Key Cryptography Standard commonly known as PKCS, including the various revisions of the published standard.
episodes.title: Describe SSL TLS Components Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie look at the security impact of commonly used hashing algorithms. They talk about verification of data origin and integrity as well as the characteristics of what successful hashing algorithms provide. They will also explain the various hashing algorithms available to implement in todays networks.
episodes.title: Describe Hashing Algorithms

episodes.description: In this episode Cherokee and Ronnie explain what encryption algorithms are, how they came into existence, and the security impact they have on our networks and lives. Cherokee clarifies the difference between transposition, substitution, block and stream ciphers. Lastly, Ronnie outlines the recommended minimum security algorithms based on use as well as selecting an algorithm based upon different security levels.
episodes.title: Encryption Algorithms and Protocols

episodes.description: Cherokee and Ronnie continue to discuss numerous types of encryption algorithms. Specifically, you will learn of their characteristics and uses. You will also learn about  a couple of protocols that are used to enhance security.
episodes.title: Encryption Algorithms and Protocols Part 2

episodes.description: Basic terminology is essential for exam taking as well as proper communication in the workforce. This show Ronnie and Cherokee cover some basic Windows terms. Altho it is not a comprehensive guide it is a good start. Topics covered include processes, threads, handles, services, memory allocation, Windows Registry, and WMI.
episodes.title: Define Windows Terms

episodes.description: This show outlines basic Linux definitions called out the exam 210-250 objectives. Ronnie and Cherokee talk about processes and  process trees. Ronnie demonstrates in a Linux Debian computer how to list running processes to view system resource utilization. Understanding what these statistics mean will help identify problematic and even potentially malicious processes on your system.
episodes.title: Define Linux Terms

episodes.description: This show is a continuation of the previous episode where Cherokee and Ronnie were discussing Linux terms. Here you will learn what a forks is how child processes are created with copy on write. You will also learn how this may be problematic and create a DOS type of attack called fork bombs. Symlink, Daemons and permissions are also explained.
episodes.title: Define Linux Terms Part 2

episodes.description: This show Ronnie and Cherokee will explain what endpoint security means, what it does and the risk associated. Other tips are covered to help harden those individual endpoints.
episodes.title: Describe Endpoint Security Monitoring

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee discuss the importance of being able to interpret log data. Ronnie demonstrates in a windows environment how to navigate the event viewer and decipher the information. He then brings up the log info for a Unix environment followed by Apache access log syntax structure.
episodes.title: Interpret OS Log Data

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee continue to interpret log information.Ronnie takes us back to the mac system to view the log information so he can explain the levels of urgency and how they relate to a numerical value. Ronnie also jumps back over to the IIS machine to show how to enable, find and interpret the information generated.
episodes.title: Interpret OS Log Data Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee talk about a method to examine network traffic. Ronnie demos a tool used in Linux environments called TCP dump. Ronnie shows how to install the tool as well as the many options available to customize your filters.
episodes.title: Identify Data Types

episodes.description: This show is a continuation of identifying data types. Specifically, Ronnie and Cherokee look at what could happen when malicious emails are received. Ronnie uses a lab environment to demo ways to view information to combat these malicious email attacks.
episodes.title: Identify Data Types Part 2

episodes.description: This show extends the previous topic where Cherokee and Ronnie explore different types of data. Ronnie demonstrates ways we can analyze data within our networks. You will see tools such as TCP Dump, Wireshark, and NetFlow being used.
episodes.title: Identify Data Types Part 3

episodes.description: This show Ronnie and Cherokee speak about different types of data that can be useful tools for network security monitoring. Full capture packets, Session data, transaction data, statistical data, extracted content and alert data can all be used to monitor our networks.
episodes.title: Describe NSM Data

episodes.description: In this show Ronnie and Cherokee look at the importance of monitoring different network components. First they observe how and where one would configure an access control list on a router. Secondly, network and port address translation is covered.
episodes.title: Describe Monitoring Context

episodes.description: This episode is a continuation of monitoring context. Cisco calls out specific ares to examine such as tunneling, TOR network traffic, encryption, P2P site traffic, encapsulation, and load balancing.
episodes.title: Describe Monitoring Context Part 2

episodes.description: this show covers different types of events that can give telling information about what is going on within your network. Ronnie demonstrates Cisco's FireSight utility to highlight these events. He shows us how to view connection, intrusion, host, network discovery and NetFlow events transpiring with the lab environment.
episodes.title: Describe NGIPS Events

episodes.description: In this show Ronnie and Cherokee discuss the importance of monitoring the protocols being used within your network. The protocols examined is Domain Name System (DNS) and Network Time Protocol (NTP). Ronnie explains weaknesses within the protocols as well as things to look for. Remember remaining vigilant and offensive is a great measure to secure your networks.
episodes.title: Monitor Protocols

episodes.description: This show is a continuation of exploring protocols that should be monitored within your network. Here you will see email protocols discussed such as simple mail transfer protocol (SMTP), post office protocol (POP), internet message access protocol (IMAP) as well as HTTP and HTTPS.
episodes.title: Monitor Protocols Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee explain several different attack concepts. First, they compare and contrast an attach surface versus vulnerabilities. You will also see attacks such as privilege escalation, social engineering, phishing, evasion methods, remote and local attacks.
episodes.title: Describe Security Attack Concepts

episodes.description: Knowing a variety of attack styles is only going to strengthen your security skill set. Cherokee and Ronnie describe Denial of Service (DOS), Distributed Denial of Service (DDOS), Man in the Middle (MitM) and SQL injection attack variations.
episodes.title: Describe Network and Web App Attacks

episodes.description: This is a continuation where Ronnie and Cherokee explain various attack styles. First, Ronnie describes types of Cross Site Scripting (XSS), Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) injection, Directory Traversal and header manipulation.
episodes.title: Describe Network and Web App Attacks Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee describe attacks and evasion methods attackers may use. First, you will learn how  a buffer overflow attack can effect a system. Followed by by types of malware such as rootkits and command and control variations. Lastly, you will learn what port scanning and host profiling is and how an attacker can benefit from these techniques.
episodes.title: Describe Attacks and Evasion Methods

episodes.description: This episode is a continuation of attacks and evasion methods. Here Ronnie and Cherokee perform a close inspection into the whys of an attack. Why would an attacker want to cause harm? By determining the why one might be able to predict the how, or the method. Next, they identify some possible methods such as encryption and tunneling, resource exhaustion, traffic fragmentation, protocol-level misinterpretation, traffic substitution and insertion as well as pivot attacks.
episodes.title: Describe Attacks and Evasion Methods Part 2
